I see how some could see there's a conflict there but there's no contradiction, it's basically two different approaches

for example, when someone attacks you, you may have a right to self defense (like in the Old Testament instances of violence) or to turn the other cheek (New Testament)

I see people complain on both sides, they'll say that if we're only supposed to turn the other cheek that that's weak, then if you mention how God doesn't mess around and will resort to violence if necessary in the Old Testament, then they'll say God is too angry, violent, and judgmental. How about God is a balanced mix?

Fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom (Proverbs 9:10), but perfect charity (love) casteth out fear (1 John 4:18). We fear God because God is all powerful and will punish people if they do wrong (or could), but after developing this respect for God's power and choosing to be good then we can love God. It's like working with a power tool like a saw - you could cut your hand so you want to be careful, but if you respect the power of the tool's ability to cut you, then you can develop a love of working with the tool.

Interesting question. God seems rather cruel and arbitrary in the OT precisely because that is how the world manifests itself to us. Remember the story of Cain in Genesis, who tried to follow his brother in sacrifice, but was confounded by The Lord nonetheless? How many times have you sacrificed and toiled for something, all for it to arbitrarily collapse? What else, in our ignorance, were we to make of Him?  
I think it's an excellent observation by our ancestors to characterise the world in such a way. It's basically 'yeah, life isn't fair, but resentment of creation on this basis will make it so much worse'.

body: A few from the 4th century actually. But the majority of scribal edits would've occurred in the earliest days; all extant manuscripts are from after the Catholic church decided on the official readings, some of which were incorrect. This is how we got things like 1 Corinthians 14:34-35 randomly interrupting in the middle of completely unrelated passages, and then the previous matter resumes afterward. The old testament situation is actually a bit worse, with significant redactions occurring at least 2 or 3 times, in 500 BC or before, long before we could have much manuscript evidence surviving to the present day. And our options are either the Septuagint which is a translation, and sometimes embarrassingly inaccurate, or the 9th century Masoretic text (recently the dead sea scrolls too, but they are incomplete).

body: What you're probably not aware of is that Paul's use of the potter and clay metaphor is based on an earlier Jewish one found in the Dead Sea Scrolls. Some Jews believed the gentiles were vessels prepared for destruction, and Jews were the objects of his glory. Basically, when Jews objected to inviting gentiles, and when Paul says they have rejected God, he is merely using their own logic against them. Basically, "You complain that gentiles are coming in now. But wait, the potter has the right to make some for glory and others for destruction, remember? So who are *you* to object?". Notice how he finishes this section with the comment that it is "so that God may have mercy on them ALL". Plus, Paul's opinion isn't absolute truth anyway.

Those two Ezekiel passages are talking about repentance though.  So even then though God does not take pleasure in the destruction of his people and wants them to repent, he's not letting them off the hook if they don't.  I don't see how that logically contradicts the idea that God chooses who he will grant life (Eph 2:10).

> To the contrary, you hold God to a moral standard of your own fashioning.

To the contrary, it is you who applies made up rules and doctrines to God.

> What does this mean? If some fail to attain mercy, has God been unable to save them despite his best efforts?

Yes, because not all of them choose to accept it.

> The unpardonable sin is such because those who commit it attribute the power of the Spirit to demons. I don't see what this has to do with predestination.

You are misunderstanding. That's what the Pharisees in this specific incident were doing, but it's not the only way it can happen. The unforgivable thing is refusing to believe, or believing and refusing to accept, while having full knowledge of the truth and the holy spirit and despising it. It's literally saying, "I know you did all of this to pardon me, but I despise you so much that I won't accept the offer". This is the whole reason why willful non-believers are not forgiven in the first place. It's not withheld from anybody, they refuse it themselves.

> God commands it. Believers are the means that he uses to grow his kingdom. And we cannot know who he will call, but we trust that he will.

But if they're already elect from the beginning of time, then what's the point?

There is no room for pride. "The saying is trustworthy and deserving of full acceptance, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners, of whom I am the foremost" (1 Tim 1:15).

You might be an exception, but many people also try to use Jesus as a tool for pride.

> I don't understand what problem you have with God's favoritism. Does he not show favoritism when he separates the sheep (those who have the righteousness of Christ) from the goats?

Because God says he does not show favoritism and is not a hypocrite. You say he is, most likely out of fleshly desire for a tyrant (our minds conflate ruthlessness with strength, and our tribal instincts want to have a strong leader more than a just one). If you think people are born as sheep or goats you are taking that parable way too literally. Sheep is a metaphor for a follower, goat is symbolic of the opposite. This parable was actually given to try and make more sheep, so if everyone was simply born one way or the other it would be pointless.
